text.p: Chad's prime minister, Djimasta Koibla, and his government tendered their resignation on Friday and President Idriss Deby accepted it, officials said.
The move followed the decision of Deby's southern rival, General Wadal Abdelkader Kamougue, on May 8 to rally to the president in the name of national unity.
Officials said Deby would nominate a new prime minister in due course.

Parliament elected Kamougue speaker of the 125-seat national assembly on May 9. "I have accepted to manage the country with President Idriss Deby to preserve democratic gains, unity and peace in Chad, which is still a fragile country," Kamougue after rallying to Deby.

Deby's Patriotic Salvation Movement (MPS) party won an 63-seat absolute majority in parliament in January and February elections. Kmougue's Union for Renewal and Democracy (URD) came second, picking up 29 seats.

Deby, a former guerrilla leader from the Moslem north, seized power in a 1990 French-backed coup after decades of civil war or conflict with Libya. After repeated electoral delays, he won a multi-party presidential poll in July.
Chad, one of the world's poorest countries, has discovered significant reserves of oil in the predominantly Christian south and north of Lake Chad.
The government has reached preliminary agreement with foreign oil companies on exploiting the oil and also envisages a pipeline to a sea terminal in Cameroon. Chad is landlocked.
